lines.text: Here, you can't go up there - she might be in bed!
Since when has a lady in bed been an object of repugnance?
What happened?
Nothing. Surprisingly little happened, considering his affectionate nature. Are all fighters affectionate?
I don't, as a rule, neck them.
Who is she, Sherry?
Therese? A graduate of the old speakeasies - ordinary, I suppose you'd call her.
I'm afraid if I ever started, I'd call her more than *that*.
I'm sorry, I thought you liked having me around more or less.
I do. More or less, either one or the other. There, now you've got it.
Tell them what you always do, darling, that what your grand-daughter does is none of their darn business.
I haven't said "darn" in twenty years.
I don't want any dinner, and I'm bored and I have a headache.
I know a cocktail that could cure two of those things, and I could cure the headache.
You know half the time I adore you and the other half the time I could murder you. I bet I'm in love.
Alas, good sir, he's made no proposals to me, improper or otherwise.

[to Sherry]
You. What's the matter with you, you slipping?

[to prizefighter]
First time I've ever seen you with your clothes on. I can't tell you how impressed I am.
Real fun isn't easy to be had.
In other words, always gay.
Exactly.

[to Oliver]
I trust you. Why don't people trust me?
Maybe it's because they know you.
And so they were married and lived unhappily ever afterwards.
I'll tell you one thing. It's going to be the most marvelous party in the world or it's going to be a Hell, so watch out.
I've always wondered if there really is a Hell.
Well, my lad, you'll have a sporting chance to find out.
Darling, I make you only one promise.
What?
I'll never call you darling unless I really mean it.
You know, my grandmother always told me to take a nap before dinner in order to conserve my vitality for the serious drinking of the evening.
Why don't women trust me?
Maybe they know you.
